comment.body: Yes, I think I will. Though there is a problem. If stars are stored in repository site, then repository author can simply add multiple json files with `{"like":true}`.

Could you please add ZeroGreeter to Git Center Index? You can do this by pressing `Publish to Repository Index` button in your repository settings.

ZeroOverflow? I tried to do that, but somewhy began to use Babel and that killed my code :)
Or ZeroExchange
Or DevPlace
No worries, I found it.

Not so important, but did you think about anonymous stories and responses?

---

You can make ZeroMedium an id-provider. Then you can accept it in `data/users/content.json`. Then add button `Login anonymously` which would call `certAdd` with some random username. After posting or responsing, `certAdd` should be called again (so a person will have different ids every time they post a message). You can find those correct arguments for `certAdd` in [Kaffie.ID](http://127.0.0.1:43110/16KzwuSAjFnivNimSHuRdPrYd1pNPhuHqN/) source code.

@Krixano:
> I will consider this.
Thanks!

> If I were to do anonymous stuff, isn't there already an anonymous id provider?
There is kaffie.id, id.zeroverse.bit and many others, but they aren't so much anonymous, and if someone posts two messages, they will have the same json_id, which is bad for anonymity.

> However, not sure if I can create new id's if I'm not using my own id provider.
You can, but then ZeroNet will ask user if he wants to change id, and that will make things look irregular (e.g. `Why did this thing ask me to change something not related? Maybe it is a virus?? Maybe my computer is infected??? AAAAAAAAAAAAA!!!`).

> The only other thing would be that anonymous stuff would kinda support spamming, so If I were to do this, I think an option to not show anonymous stuff might be useful for people who don't want to see anonymous posts/comments.
Yeah, spamming is what I didn't think about. Though, you support kaffie.id and crypto.id, so if someone would want to spam you, they could do that using kaffie.id and crypto.id.

> I think having this would be more important for stories rather than comments.
Yeah, stories are important, but comments are imporant too. E.g. if you want to answer question on your anonymous story, revealing isn't expected.

> I could also just add a setting marking a story as anonymous.
Yes, perhaps a good way too.

> Anyways, Interesting idea. Thanks.
Thank *you* for such project.
What editor are you using?

@Krixano:
> It is important to have anonymity for comments. What I meant by stories being more important is that being able to filter/hide anonymous stories would be more important than filtering/hiding anonymous comments.
Yes, I didn't understand you back then. Now I agree.

> Also, the anonymous id provider I was thinking of was `ifs.anonymous` and `0ch.anonymous` which I believe are used for ZeroNet proxies.
Though I don't want to argue, they are not anonymous. They are pseudonymous, i.e. if someone sends 5 comments, they would have the same author. And if you use your own id provider, you could (probably) change id after every post.

@Binchan2:
> Merger site feature like Git Center so user can fully control his own content but still you and later other moderators can moderate the content by configuring ZeroMedium itself.
A good idea. @Krixano: Do you see any problems here?

Hooray! Glad you started to work on `ZeroNet Dev Center` again. Also, I wrote some tutorials before (for both users and developers) and sent you [an issue](https://github.com/krixano/ZeroNet-Dev-Center/issues/28), but you said you were too busy. Could you have a look at them now?
@Krixano: I think it's better to integrate them into the tutorials. I wrote it spontaneous, and much is messy. Collaborating would help, maybe on GitHub.

A2: I think the best is to be able to change username, like on SO. But, if it is too difficult to implement, you can take ZeroID, remove `@zeroid.bit` and use TitleCase, e.g. `gitcenter@zeroid.bit` -> `Gitcenter`.

@Krixano: Sorry for my misunderstanding.

> I have never said it did this. Read again.

> It's not. They are different. If it was a typo, then all of my zites, which have used the public key listed, would not work with KaffieId, but they do.

> I never said this. I said that public key, which is clearly explained (on KaffieId page) that it should be put in the data/users/content.json file to allow users to use KaffieId on your zite, is used to decrypt an encrypted signature. If anybody can use KaffieId to create an account, they need a signature which can be decrypted by this public key, therefore the private key to it must be public (listed in the code at the very least).

I understood `private key is published` as `private key is used to add a new user to database`.

> Sure, databases can be maintained by zite owner only. But when they are not, they are associated directly with a user id. Heck, they are even placed insider user folders. How is that not a direct link. Direct meaning that you need to understand users to understand databases in which users can add to it and you need to understand databases to understand the purpose of users in the first place.

If that is what you meant, then you are right.

> I'm pretty sure I've already explicitly stated I was going to not only create more tutorials, but also use yours (upon your permission). This tutorial was also explicitly stated, at the very beginning of it, to be a very basic tutorial "so that both users and developers can understand these as a fundamental part of all zites on the ZeroNet. " The purpose of this tutorial is to be a primer for more tutorials for developers, but also be a basics tutorials for users who need not go further in depth.

Yeah, for a basic tutorial this is enough. Maybe skipped that part saying about being only beginning.

> There you go. As you can see, the private key is public and using bitcoinjs to get it's matching public key, it matches the public key given on the KaffieId page, which is used by ZeroNet to decrypt user id signatures that were encrypted by this private key on your computer during registration on the kaffieid website.

Learning something new everyday :)

> A search engine that doesn't track you.

This is like saying `An apple that isn't black.` :) I know no engine that uses external files (except EulerFinder that uses miner).
@Mv00: idem
@Krixano: `a publicly available private key` wasn't enough clear. I understood that as `a publicly available private key of kaffie.id`.

@Krixano:

> It's not. They are different. If it was a typo, then all of my zites, which have used the public key listed, would not work with KaffieId, but they do.

I thought that zites usually use *their* public keys as auth providers. But it turns out any bitcoin private key can be such a provider.

Also, do you know when are ZeroID users verified? E.g. can I change my `data/users/.../content.json`'s `cert_user_id` to `nofish@zeroid.bit` and signature to use `nofish`? So I won't use nofish's auth_address, but users would think I am nofish.
@Krixano: But you say signature is copied to both local `users.json` and remote, ZeroID `users.json`. Then, why cannot I take nofish's signature from remote `users.json` and paste it to my local?

@Krixano: Oh yes, I see now. `auth_address` is also in signature, and if I want to change it to e.g. my address, I have to resign signature, which is not possible 'cause I don't have ZeroID private key.

Thanks for expaination!

Yeah, but seems like most here are developers which love to make things... They just love to make, not to use. E.g. how much people use ZeroVoat or ZeroMedium? We just have too many techy people here, when we need simple users for what we make.
